info.content:
The data presented for Victoria in AREMI are the results of modelling the quantities of biomass residue generated throughout the state across Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) and several industries in the Commercial and Industrial (C&I) and Construction and Demolition (C&D) sectors.

Data for all modelled residue generation has been presented at a Local Government Area (LGA) equivalent. Due to the prominent use of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) datasets across this study, data has been presented at Statistical Area 2 level (SA2),an Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS) that is part of the ABS geographical framework for collection and dissemination of geographically classified statistics. SA2s are general-purpose medium sized areas, representing a community that interacts together socially and economically and generally have a population range of 3,000 to 25,000 persons. They can be linked to LGAs through correspondence tables that ABS provides.

The categorisation of wastes has considered the end nature of the wastes to be used in energy production. Therefore, an indication of whether a residue is dry, wet, liquid or woody has been provided where possible. They have been discussed below.

Dry and woody feed: For consistency, data has where possible been provided in dry tonnes per annum, taking into consideration the moisture content of residue streams, or left as tonnes per annum where application of a moisture content is not feasible due to the inconsistent nature of the organics waste stream or data.

Wet feed: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is a measure of the total organic compounds in water by providing an indication of the total oxygen required to fully oxidise those compounds. COD differs from Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) in that it considers organic matter than can be chemical oxidised and not just biologically. COD therefore includes more organic compounds (than BOD), and is commonly used for testing industrial wastewaters, a key output from most commercial facilities. COD is also used to predict the potential for biogas production and the COD present in organic material is essentially preserved in the AD end products of methane and digestate residue mass. Hence, where wastewater have been modelled, the residues have been provided in COD tonnes per year.

Liquid feed: Compared to wastewater, the main component contributing to the organic strength of sludge and manure is organic Suspended Solids (SS). From an energy generation perspective, the most important metrics in characterising these slurries are Total Solids content (TS) and Volatile Solids content (VS), rather than COD. When considering biogas production from a slurry, the VS content is more important than TS as it represents the fraction of the solid material that may be transferred to biogas. Hence, quantities of residue from manures or slurries have been presented in VS tonnes per year.

The types of residues modelled are based on an assessment of the availability of the stream, such as where the current offtake markets have little value or disposal costs are low.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.
info.name: Project Information

info.content:
Organic waste (organics being food, garden and timber wastes and paper and cardboard) generated from the Commercial & Industrial (C&I) waste stream in Victoria was modelled using industry reports and ABS data. The data in this folder excludes the manufacturing and agricultural sectors, which were considered separately.

The Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) system was used as the basis for categorising and defining the C&I sector in terms of organics waste generation. The ANZSIC system provides a framework for organising data about business types. It provides a standard framework under which units carrying out similar productive activities can be grouped together, with each resultant group being referred to as an industry. There is a total of 19 classes, with each individual class defined in terms of a specified range of activities. The numbering system adopted in the ANZSIC system is a combination of letter characters and numeric coding and has a hierarchical structure, where the leading character denotes the industry division. A total of 12 classes were considered through this modelling.

In the absence of local data providing waste generation or compositional breakdown at ANZSIC division level, a desktop study was conducted to find comparable baseline statistics. Waste generation rates per full time equivalent (FTE) employee for each ANZSIC industry division in the Victorian commercial and industrial sector have been sourced from the Sustainable Resource Use (SRU, 2013) report prepared for Sustainability Victoria. Compositional waste stream data for each ANZSIC industry division have been sourced from the NSW EPA (2015) publication, ‘Pilot generator site-based audit, commercial and Industrial waste stream in the metropolitan levy areas of New South Wales’, and details have been provided in the biomass description field.The Department of Employment publishes total employment figures by industry division at SA4 level, through the Labour Market Information Portal (LMIP). This data is collected through the ABS quarterly labour force surveys. This employment data was disaggregated using the ABS publication ‘8165.0 Counts of Australian Businesses, Including Entries and Exists (CABEE), June 2013 to June 2017’, which provides estimates of the number of businesses of each industry division at LGA equivalent level across Victoria.

Using the SRU Victorian waste generation rates, ABS labour count and business information and NSW compositional audit data, estimates of total organics and paper cardboard generation from 12 ANZSIC industry divisions has been modelled.The results provide estimations of residue quantities based on business counts in 2016-17.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.

In the absence of local data providing waste generation or compositional breakdown at ANZSIC division level, a desktop study was conducted to find comparable baseline statistics. Waste generation rates per full time equivalent (FTE) employee for each ANZSIC industry division in the Victorian commercial and industrial sector have been sourced from the Sustainable Resource Use (SRU, 2013) report prepared for Sustainability Victoria. Compositional waste stream data for each ANZSIC industry division have been sourced from the NSW EPA (2015) publication, ‘Pilot generator site-based audit, commercial and Industrial waste stream in the metropolitan levy areas of New South Wales’, and details have been provided in the biomass description field.The Department of Employment publishes total employment figures by industry division at SA4 level, through the Labour Market Information Portal (LMIP). This data is collected through the ABS quarterly labour force surveys. This employment data was disaggregated using the ABS publication ‘8165.0 Counts of Australian Businesses, Including Entries and Exists (CABEE), June 2013 to June 2017’, which provides estimates of the number of businesses of each industry division at LGA equivalent level across Victoria.

Using the SRU Victorian waste generation rates, ABS labour count and business information and NSW compositional audit data, estimates of total organics and paper cardboard generation from 12 ANZSIC industry divisions has been modelled.The results provide estimations of residue quantities based on business counts in 2016-17.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.

info.content:
The data presented for Victoria in AREMI are the results of modelling the quantities of biomass residue generated throughout the state across Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) and several industries in the Commercial and Industrial (C&I) and Construction and Demolition (C&D) sectors.

Data for all modelled residue generation has been presented at a Local Government Area (LGA) equivalent. Due to the prominent use of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) datasets across this study, data has been presented at Statistical Area 2 level (SA2),an Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS) that is part of the ABS geographical framework for collection and dissemination of geographically classified statistics. SA2s are general-purpose medium sized areas, representing a community that interacts together socially and economically and generally have a population range of 3,000 to 25,000 persons. They can be linked to LGAs through correspondence tables that ABS provides.

The categorisation of wastes has considered the end nature of the wastes to be used in energy production. Therefore, an indication of whether a residue is dry, wet, liquid or woody has been provided where possible. They have been discussed below.

Dry and woody feed: For consistency, data has where possible been provided in dry tonnes per annum, taking into consideration the moisture content of residue streams, or left as tonnes per annum where application of a moisture content is not feasible due to the inconsistent nature of the organics waste stream or data.

Wet feed: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is a measure of the total organic compounds in water by providing an indication of the total oxygen required to fully oxidise those compounds. COD differs from Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) in that it considers organic matter than can be chemical oxidised and not just biologically. COD therefore includes more organic compounds (than BOD), and is commonly used for testing industrial wastewaters, a key output from most commercial facilities. COD is also used to predict the potential for biogas production and the COD present in organic material is essentially preserved in the AD end products of methane and digestate residue mass. Hence, where wastewater have been modelled, the residues have been provided in COD tonnes per year.

Liquid feed: Compared to wastewater, the main component contributing to the organic strength of sludge and manure is organic Suspended Solids (SS). From an energy generation perspective, the most important metrics in characterising these slurries are Total Solids content (TS) and Volatile Solids content (VS), rather than COD. When considering biogas production from a slurry, the VS content is more important than TS as it represents the fraction of the solid material that may be transferred to biogas. Hence, quantities of residue from manures or slurries have been presented in VS tonnes per year.

The types of residues modelled are based on an assessment of the availability of the stream, such as where the current offtake markets have little value or disposal costs are low.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.
info.name: Project Information

info.content:
This data has been modelled to represent the total estimated forestry residues from Victorian softwood (Pinus radiata) and hardwood (Eucalyptus globulus) plantations at Local Government Area (LGA) level. Forestry residue dry mass was estimated from data on sawlog and pulp log production available from ABARES (2016a) and spatial data on showing plantation areas obtained from ABARES (2016b). Because the number of logs harvested from hardwood plantations has been increasing substantially over time, data for future log production (2016-20) was used.

Log production is available only at a state or regional level. So, to estimate forestry residue amounts at an LGA level, the area of hardwood and softwood plantations at an LGA level was used with the assumption that the number of logs produced was the same for each hectare of plantation. To convert wood volumes to dry mass, wood density estimates (Illic, et al.2000) for P.radiata and E. globulus were used.

Residue amounts were estimated by applying residue factors derived from Ximenes et al. (2008), Greaves & May (2012) and information provided by various plantation growers for softwood and hardwood species. Residues were separated into the following categories:

  • Stump
  • Bark
  • Branches (>5 cm)
  • Twigs (< 5 cm) branches and foliage (all assumed to be left on site)

A proportion of each residue type (ranging from 0% for stumps to 100% for small branches and foliage) was assumed to be unavailable due to difficulty in collection and/or the need to conserve nutrients on site.

info.content:
Sawmill residues were estimated at an LGA level using forest product data for native forests and plantations, spatial data showing locations of plantations, regional data on wood production from native forests, wood density data and sawmill residue.

Production of sawlogs and sawn timber for the whole of Victoria was sourced from ABARES (2016a) for native forests (covering the period 2011-15) and from ABARES (2016b) for plantations (covering the period 2016-2020). The reason for the later time period used for plantation log supply was the sharp increase in plantation log production over time.Since many sawlogs produced from Victorian forests are processed in other states or exported overseas, the proportion of residues processed in Victoria was estimated from the ratio between total amount of sawn timber produced across the state for the period 2011-15 and the expected total production of sawn timber from plantations and native forests over the same period based on the total number of sawlogs produced and sawn timber recovery rates (Gavran 2014). This statewide data was distributed at an LGA level using spatial data showing the locations of plantations (ABARES 2016b) and regional production data provided by Vicforests (M. Lawrence Pers. Comm.).

Total sawmill residues were estimated from the number of sawlogs processed using results Gavran et al. (2014) and were converted from volumes to dry mass using wood densities sourced from Illic et al. (2000). These totals were divided into the following residue categories using proportions estimated by Greaves and May (2014):

  • Woodchips
  • Sawdust and shavings
  • Bark

It should be noted that most sawmill residues are currently utilised. Wood chips are mostly used for pulp and paper production (either locally or exported overseas), sawdust and shavings are burnt for heat production to kiln dry timber, and bark and sawdust are sold for potting mix or animal bedding.

Production of sawlogs and sawn timber for the whole of Victoria was sourced from ABARES (2016a) for native forests (covering the period 2011-15) and from ABARES (2016b) for plantations (covering the period 2016-2020). The reason for the later time period used for plantation log supply was the sharp increase in plantation log production over time.Since many sawlogs produced from Victorian forests are processed in other states or exported overseas, the proportion of residues processed in Victoria was estimated from the ratio between total amount of sawn timber produced across the state for the period 2011-15 and the expected total production of sawn timber from plantations and native forests over the same period based on the total number of sawlogs produced and sawn timber recovery rates (Gavran 2014). This statewide data was distributed at an LGA level using spatial data showing the locations of plantations (ABARES 2016b) and regional production data provided by Vicforests (M. Lawrence Pers. Comm.).

Total sawmill residues were estimated from the number of sawlogs processed using results Gavran et al. (2014) and were converted from volumes to dry mass using wood densities sourced from Illic et al. (2000). These totals were divided into the following residue categories using proportions estimated by Greaves and May (2014):

  • Woodchips
  • Sawdust and shavings
  • Bark

It should be noted that most sawmill residues are currently utilised. Wood chips are mostly used for pulp and paper production (either locally or exported overseas), sawdust and shavings are burnt for heat production to kiln dry timber, and bark and sawdust are sold for potting mix or animal bedding.

info.content:
The data presented for Victoria in AREMI are the results of modelling the quantities of biomass residue generated throughout the state across Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) and several industries in the Commercial and Industrial (C&I) and Construction and Demolition (C&D) sectors.

Data for all modelled residue generation has been presented at a Local Government Area (LGA) equivalent. Due to the prominent use of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) datasets across this study, data has been presented at Statistical Area 2 level (SA2),an Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS) that is part of the ABS geographical framework for collection and dissemination of geographically classified statistics. SA2s are general-purpose medium sized areas, representing a community that interacts together socially and economically and generally have a population range of 3,000 to 25,000 persons. They can be linked to LGAs through correspondence tables that ABS provides.

The categorisation of wastes has considered the end nature of the wastes to be used in energy production. Therefore, an indication of whether a residue is dry, wet, liquid or woody has been provided where possible. They have been discussed below.

Dry and woody feed: For consistency, data has where possible been provided in dry tonnes per annum, taking into consideration the moisture content of residue streams, or left as tonnes per annum where application of a moisture content is not feasible due to the inconsistent nature of the organics waste stream or data.

Wet feed: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is a measure of the total organic compounds in water by providing an indication of the total oxygen required to fully oxidise those compounds. COD differs from Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) in that it considers organic matter than can be chemical oxidised and not just biologically. COD therefore includes more organic compounds (than BOD), and is commonly used for testing industrial wastewaters, a key output from most commercial facilities. COD is also used to predict the potential for biogas production and the COD present in organic material is essentially preserved in the AD end products of methane and digestate residue mass. Hence, where wastewater have been modelled, the residues have been provided in COD tonnes per year.

Liquid feed: Compared to wastewater, the main component contributing to the organic strength of sludge and manure is organic Suspended Solids (SS). From an energy generation perspective, the most important metrics in characterising these slurries are Total Solids content (TS) and Volatile Solids content (VS), rather than COD. When considering biogas production from a slurry, the VS content is more important than TS as it represents the fraction of the solid material that may be transferred to biogas. Hence, quantities of residue from manures or slurries have been presented in VS tonnes per year.

The types of residues modelled are based on an assessment of the availability of the stream, such as where the current offtake markets have little value or disposal costs are low.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.
info.name: Project Information

info.content:
The core dataset used in determining baseline production quantities for the primary production sector is the ABS Agricultural Commodities datasets. ABS data has been used from 2010-11 to 2015-16, to provide a time-series average of production from a variety of agricultural commodities.

Residue factors were applied to the six year average production values based on desktop research and industry consultation and feedback. This includes the following:

  • Cereals – straw and chaff
  • Non-Cereals – oilseed pods
  • Cull Fruit
  • Cull Vegetable
  • Dairy Manure
  • Piggery Manure
  • Poultry Litter

The results provide estimations of residue quantities generated based on a six-year average of primary production data.For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.

info.content:
The data presented for Victoria in AREMI are the results of modelling the quantities of biomass residue generated throughout the state across Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) and several industries in the Commercial and Industrial (C&I) and Construction and Demolition (C&D) sectors.

Data for all modelled residue generation has been presented at a Local Government Area (LGA) equivalent. Due to the prominent use of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) datasets across this study, data has been presented at Statistical Area 2 level (SA2),an Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS) that is part of the ABS geographical framework for collection and dissemination of geographically classified statistics. SA2s are general-purpose medium sized areas, representing a community that interacts together socially and economically and generally have a population range of 3,000 to 25,000 persons. They can be linked to LGAs through correspondence tables that ABS provides.

The categorisation of wastes has considered the end nature of the wastes to be used in energy production. Therefore, an indication of whether a residue is dry, wet, liquid or woody has been provided where possible. They have been discussed below.

Dry and woody feed: For consistency, data has where possible been provided in dry tonnes per annum, taking into consideration the moisture content of residue streams, or left as tonnes per annum where application of a moisture content is not feasible due to the inconsistent nature of the organics waste stream or data.

Wet feed: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is a measure of the total organic compounds in water by providing an indication of the total oxygen required to fully oxidise those compounds. COD differs from Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) in that it considers organic matter than can be chemical oxidised and not just biologically. COD therefore includes more organic compounds (than BOD), and is commonly used for testing industrial wastewaters, a key output from most commercial facilities. COD is also used to predict the potential for biogas production and the COD present in organic material is essentially preserved in the AD end products of methane and digestate residue mass. Hence, where wastewater have been modelled, the residues have been provided in COD tonnes per year.

Liquid feed: Compared to wastewater, the main component contributing to the organic strength of sludge and manure is organic Suspended Solids (SS). From an energy generation perspective, the most important metrics in characterising these slurries are Total Solids content (TS) and Volatile Solids content (VS), rather than COD. When considering biogas production from a slurry, the VS content is more important than TS as it represents the fraction of the solid material that may be transferred to biogas. Hence, quantities of residue from manures or slurries have been presented in VS tonnes per year.

The types of residues modelled are based on an assessment of the availability of the stream, such as where the current offtake markets have little value or disposal costs are low.

For more information on the modelling methodology, or if you are a generator and would like to provide feedback to improve the assumptions, please contact Kelly Wickham at kelly.wickham@sustainability.vic.gov.au.

If you have queries about using the data for your project or would like more information about how Sustainability Victoria may be able to assist you, please contact the Investment Facilitation Services team at invest@sustainability.vic.gov.au, +61 3 8626 8746.

info.content: The MSW organics data has been presented for the organics (garden mostly, although some select councils in Victoria operate food and garden organic (FOGO) systems) and paper and cardboard streams at LGA level. Only organics that are landfilled have been presented (compared to other streams where generation has been presented). This is due to the fact that most MSW organics are tied up in long term contract and presenting generation would be an unrealistic presentation of this stream (although noting that energy from MSW organics could be a higher order use than current avenues in some LGAs). The data is raw data obtained from LGAs through the Victorian Local Government Annual Survey (VLGAS) conducted by SV.

items.name: Western Australia
items.description:
WA AREMI

Welcome to the Western Australian section of the AREMI mapping resource. This is a national interactive mapping database providing information on biomass quantity and spatial distribution that may be available for a range of uses including for the Bioeconomy.

A number of layers have been developed providing information on residues from the main agricultural crop and livestock industries as well as plantation forestry and municipal waste. The available layers include residue information from,

  • Cereal crops
  • Annual horticulture (multiple crops)
  • Perennial horticulture
  • Hard and softwood plantations
  • Oil Mallee plantations
  • Intensive animal industries (poultry, dairy and cattle feedlots)
  • Municipal solid waste
  • Commercial and industrial waste
  • Construction and demolition waste
  • Seaweed wrack

To add a layer, click on the feedstock layer you are interested in from the drop down list. Further layers can be added by clicking on the ‘Add Data’ tab.

For further information contact:
Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development
Kim Brooksbank
Email: kim.brooksbank@dpird.wa.gov.au

Ron Master
Email:ronald.master@dpird.wa.gov.au

items.name: Cereal straw
items.dataCustodian: [Department of Agriculture and Food, Western Australia](https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/)
items.description: Data summarizes per hectare residue yields that are based on a average yields from estimates of five years of data (2006 - 2010), to give an indication of likely yield of cereal residue per shire in Western Australia.  Residue estimates were calculated using an unpublished Crop Residue Estimates Model developed by, Plunkett, B Senior Economist with the Department of Agriculture and Food Western Australia,  based on an average of publically available crop estimates from 2006 - 2010 (data included representations of high, low and average seasons).

items.name: Grape Marc
items.dataCustodian: [Department of Agriculture and Food, Western Australia](https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/)
items.description:
Grape marc volumes have been estimated by using a conversion factor from the amounts that are listed as crushed in publicly available documents. Grape marc volumes from crushed grapes can vary greatly, and a range of13 – 35% has been cited in the literature. For this data we have used a conversion factor of 20% wet weight based on the following publications (Corbin et al., 2015; Ky and Teissedre, 2015; Mazza and Francis, 1995).
Crushed grape volumes are reported in broad categories and as a result volumes of grape marc that are actually produced may vary from what is reported. However, data should give a good indication of what is available at each location.
References:
  1. Corbin, K.R., Hsieh, Y.S.Y., Betts, N.S., Byrt, C.S., Henderson, M., Stork, J., DeBolt, S., Fincher, G.B.,
  2. Mazza, G., Francis, F.J., 1995. Anthocyanins in grapes and grape products. Crit. Rev. Food Sci. Nutr. 35, 341-371.

Depth of model prediction: 2km

info.name: Summary
info.content:
This raster dataset shows the calculated temperatures of the underlying geology at 2km depth. The dataset is represented here as a NSW statewide geothermal temperature map at 2km depth.

The Geological Survey of NSW developed the Geothermal Borehole Database and geothermal 2, 3 and 5km temperature maps in 2015-2016 as part of the renewable energy resource maps for the NSW Renewable Energy Action Plan, Annual Report 2015. The aim of the Geothermal Borehole Database and the renewable energy resource and maps were to;

(i) Develop an up-to-date NSW borehole temperature database from all available internal and external data sources(ii) Extrapolate temperature readings from varying depths to 2, 3 and 5km levels using calculations(iii) Produce statewide temperature maps from the Geothermal Borehole Database for 2, 3 and 5km depths illustrating high and low temperature areas.

info.name: NSW Department of Industry Disclaimer
info.content:
The information contained in this publication is based on knowledge and understanding at the time of compilation (2016). However, because of advances in knowledge, users are reminded of the need to ensure that information upon which they rely is up to date.

NSW Department of Industry takes no responsibility for the accuracy, currency, reliability and correctness of any information in the map (including, without limitation, any of the information provided by third parties) nor for the accuracy, currency, reliability and correctness of links or references to information sources (including Internet sites) with regard to the map.

featureInfoTemplate.name: {{GRAY_INDEX}} C
featureInfoTemplate.template:
Temperature: {{GRAY_INDEX}} C

Depth of model prediction: 3km

info.name: Summary
info.content:
This raster dataset shows the calculated temperatures of the underlying geology at 3km depth. The dataset is represented here as a NSW statewide geothermal temperature map at 3km depth.

The Geological Survey of NSW developed the Geothermal Borehole Database and geothermal 2, 3 and 5km temperature maps in 2015-2016 as part of the renewable energy resource maps for the NSW Renewable Energy Action Plan, Annual Report 2015. The aim of the Geothermal Borehole Database and the renewable energy resource and maps were to;

(i) Develop an up-to-date NSW borehole temperature database from all available internal and external data sources(ii) Extrapolate temperature readings from varying depths to 2, 3 and 5km levels using calculations(iii) Produce statewide temperature maps from the Geothermal Borehole Database for 2, 3 and 5km depths illustrating high and low temperature areas.

items.name: Australia Upper Reservoir Locations - ANU STORES

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
None of the PHES sites discussed in this study have been the subject of geological, hydrological, environmental and other studies, and it is not known whether any particular site would be suitable.

Please refer to the ANU 100% Renewable Energy website for additional information:

http://re100.eng.anu.edu.au/

There has been no investigation of land tenure apart from exclusion of national parks and urban areas, and no discussions with land owners and managers. Nothing in this list of potential site locations implies any rights for development of these locations.

The commercial feasibility of developing these sites is unknown. As with all major engineering projects, diligent attention to quality assurance would be required for safety and efficacy.

items.name: ANU STORES Worldwide
items.description:
As the proportion of wind and solar photovoltaics (PV) in an electrical grid extends into the 50-100% range a combination of additional long-distance high voltage transmission, demand management and local storage is required for stability. Pumped Hydro Energy Storage (PHES) constitutes 97% of electricity storage worldwide because of its low cost.

The RE100 Group ANU found about 530,000 potentially feasible PHES sites with storage potential of about 22 million Gigawatt-hours (GWh) by using geographic information system (GIS) analysis. This is about one hundred times greater than required to support a 100% global renewable electricity system. Brownfield sites (existing reservoirs, old mining sites) will be included in a future analysis.

This information has been developed by the 100% Renewable Energy group from the Research School of Electrical, Energy and Materials Engineering at the Australia National University. http://re100.eng.anu.edu.au

Potential sites for off-river PHES are identified using GIS algorithms with defined search criteria. The surveyed latitude range is up to 60 degrees north and south. Each identified site comprises an upper and lower reservoir pair plus a hypothetical tunnel route between the reservoirs, and includes data such as latitude, longitude, altitude, head, slope, water volume, water area, rock volume, dam wall length, water/rock ratio, energy storage potential and approximate relative cost (categories A-E).

Wall heights are adjusted for each reservoir in a pair to yield equal water volumes to achieve the targeted energy storage. Energy (= head * usable volume * g * efficiency) and storage-length combinations are provided in Table 1. The approximate number of people that a reservoirs could service for a 100% renewable electricity grid is listed in the third line.

Table 1 2 GWh 5 GWh 15 GWh 50 GWh 150 GWh
6 hours ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ -
18 hours - ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓
Millions of people 0.1 0.25 0.75 2.5 7.5

Virtually all upper reservoirs are away from rivers, and none intrude on protected area or urban areas listed in the databases that we use below. There may be local constraints that prevent use of a particular site that is not reflected in these databases. Please refer to the ANU 100% Renewable Energy website for additional information: http://re100.eng.anu.edu.au/global

DISCLAIMER

None of the PHES sites discussed in this study have been the subject of geological, hydrological, environmental, heritage and other studies, and it is not known whether any particular site would be suitable. The commercial feasibility of developing these sites is unknown. As with all major engineering projects, diligent attention to quality assurance would be required for safety and efficacy.

There has been no investigation of land tenure apart from exclusion of some environmental areas and urban areas, and no discussions with land owners and managers. Nothing in this list of potential site locations implies any rights for development of these locations. Accuracy of the sites depends on the accuracy of the source data. There may be sites that fall into local protected areas or urban areas that are not identified by the source data.

Please refer to the ANU 100% Renewable Energy website for additional information: http://re100.eng.anu.edu.au/global

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
None of the PHES sites discussed in this study have been the subject of geological, hydrological, environmental, heritage and other studies, and it is not known whether any particular site would be suitable. The commercial feasibility of developing these sites is unknown. As with all major engineering projects, diligent attention to quality assurance would be required for safety and efficacy.

There has been no investigation of land tenure apart from exclusion of some environmental areas and urban areas, and no discussions with land owners and managers. Nothing in this list of potential site locations implies any rights for development of these locations. Accuracy of the sites depends on the accuracy of the source data. There may be sites that fall into local protected areas or urban areas that are not identified by the source data.

items.name: Australian Marine Energy Atlas
items.description:
Australian Marine Energy Atlas

The Australian Marine Energy Atlas has been compiled by CSIRO Oceans and Atmosphere. The Atlas provides interactive maps of wave and tidal energy resources for Australia’s marine estate, with further available information on supporting infrastructure and spatial constraints in the marine domain. The Atlas compiles output from several projects. Notably the CSIRO led Australian Wave Energy Atlas Project, and the University of Tasmania led Australian Tidal Energy (AUSTEn) project, both supported by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), building on prior CSIRO assessments of Australia's marine energy resources. The Atlas makes it easier to assess the feasibility of potential marine energy projects. The online Atlas has used data from weather mapping, satellites, in-situ measuring stations and a variety of other sources, which have supported development of marine and hydrodynamic modelling applications.

The online Atlas has 3 main components:

  1. Multiple use layers - which contains geographic information on other uses of the marine domain, including supporting, complementary and potentially competing requirements (e.g., Ports, Shipping and Fishing information);
  2. Wave Energy Resource - includes geographic layers reflecting characteristics of Australia’s wave energy resource, and analysis tools for further data interrogation;
  3. Tidal Energy Resource - includes geographic layers reflecting characteristics of Australia’s tidal energy resource, and analysis tools for further data interrogation.

The analysis tools of the Australian Marine Energy Atlas provides unique functionality in AREMI. Below are the steps to access and query the Atlas information:

  • Click on 'Analysis Tools' and then scroll down to select a type of analysis;
  • Once the type of analysis has been selected, to enable a query, a location needs to be selected; either by clicking on point within the 'Analysis Study Area' highlighted in grey or by typing the exact lat/long;
  • Once the location point has been selected, click on 'Run Analysis'; an image with the analysis results will appear in the workbench.

info.name: Data Supplier and Processing
info.content: The data is supplied by the Electric Vehicle Council. Data is processed and by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS) for display on AREMI.

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Data is updated 6-monthly in June and December.

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is an Australia-wide map of the number and location of current Electric Vehicle (EV) charging stations. The ‘plug type’ displayed refers to the charging plug(s) available at the station. Note that some stations are plotted directly on top of each other where multiple network providers and/or charge heads of differing types are at the same site. The details of all the chargers can be accessed by selecting the feature and looking through the feature info box

The following additional ‘display variables’ can also be selected in the legend panel: charger type, No. of vehicles which can simultaneously charge, charging network, power (kW) and Hardware brand. When 'No. of vehicles which can simultaneously charge' or 'Power (kW)' is selected as display variable, points are additionally scaled in size by their numeric value of the selected variable.

In the context of Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning, these variables are important to understand gaps in the existing charging infrastructure provision.

Click on a charging station to reveal the following information:

  • Name
  • Location details such as address, latitude and longitude
  • Charger type: AC (Level 2) / DC (Level 3) information on power level and whether the charger uses Alternating Current (AC) or Direct Current (DC)
  • Plug types: Specifies the relevant plug type compatibility, as each charging station will only be capable of connecting certain electric vehicle models.
  • Charging network: The charging network to which the station belongs. Non-networked stations refer to those openly accessible to all EV owners, not only those that are part of a given charging network.
  • Power (kW): Where available, the output power of charginge station at the charging plug (kW).
  • Hardware brand: Where available, the manufacturer of charging station hardware.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
This data layer provides information on locations and characteristics of current Electric Vehicle Charging infrastructure, to inform potential gaps in the network and opportunities for extending the charging network. You are free to use the data but do so at your own risk. While due care and attention has been taken in the compilation and presentation of the data, the Providers of these maps do not make any representations, guarantees or warranties as to the accuracy, reliability, completeness or currency of the data and content of the maps.

By viewing or downloading the data the user agrees to irrevocably release the creators, authors, publishers and contributors to the maps, who include the Electric Vehicle Council and its members, and UTS (‘the ‘Providers’), from all claims, actions, damages, judgments, losses, remedies or matters whether in tort, contract or under statute or otherwise, relating to the data. By proceeding, the user releases the Providers from all liability, and accepts the terms of this Disclaimer.

items.name: EV registrations by postcode

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is a NSW map of total number of Electric Vehicle (EV) registrations by postcode for a specified year. Use the time slider bar at the bottom to explore how registrations have changed since 2017.

In the context of Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning, this is a critical variable that indicates growth areas for EV uptake and potential demand for charging services.

The display shows the number of vehicles that registered in that year, regardless of whether they are a new registration or a re-registration;

For example, if an owner bought a new vehicle and initiallly registered it in 2017, reregistered in 2018, but let registration lapse in 2019. Then the resulting data for each year due to this vehicle will be:

  • 2017: 1 vehicle
  • 2018: 1 vehicle
  • 2019: 0 vehicles

Click on a postcode region to reveal the following information:

  • Postcode
  • LGA: Local Government Area name where EVs are registered
  • Registration count broken down by:
    • body type (sedans vs coupes)
    • make
    • (primary) use
    • year of manufacture
  • Link to ABS Census Quickstats for this postcode: to get a rapid appraisal of socio-demographic characteristics.

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Data is updated 6-monthly in June and December.

info.name: Data Supplier and Processing
info.content: The data is supplied by the NSW Government Roads and Maritime Services. Data is processed and hosted by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS) for display on AREMI.

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
The Data presented is derived from third party Address Data provided by the registered owners of electric powered vehicles. You acknowledge that the Address Data provided by the registered owner of a vehicle may not always accurately represent the geographical location of that vehicle, and that the Address Data is subject to change from time to time. Transport for NSW has not independently verified the Address Data the Data relies on.

Transport for NSW does not warrant, represent or guarantee the accuracy or suitability for any purpose of the information (including the Data) published at this website.

Transport for NSW does not accept any legal liability for any loss or damage arising directly or indirectly from any person’s use of information (including the Data) published at this website. You hereby release Transport for NSW, including its officers, agents and contractors, from all actions, suits, claims, demands, costs, damages and expenses which You might have against Transport for NSW, including its officers, agents and contractors, for any loss or damage of whatsoever nature and howsoever arising in connection with Your use of the information (including the Data) published at this website.

Use of information (including the Data) published at this website is at Your sole risk. Transport for NSW recommends that You exercise Your own skill, care and judgment with respect to Your use of information (including the Data) published. You must seek Your own appropriate independent professional advice before making any decision based on information (including the Data) published at this website.

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is a NSW map of average hourly weekday traffic volumes at different monitoring stations, recorded in average number of vehicles per hour on all weekdays of the year (i.e. excluding weekends but not holidays). Data displayed is for the primary direction of travel specified (east-west or north-south). Data presented is for the most recent available year.

In the context of Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning, this is a critical variable that indicates potential volume and timing of charging needs, dictated by passing road traffic.

Click on a monitoring station to reveal the following information:

  • Station name
  • Station ID: Code used to identify specific monitoring station
  • LGA; Suburb: Local Government Area and suburb in which the monitoring station is located
  • Road type: Motorway, Arterial road, Sub-Arterial Road, Distributor Road, Primary Road
  • Primary direction captured: Direction of travel presented in the data
  • Average hourly weekday table: All 24hrs presented separately chart is provided for the daily variations underpinning the average figures.
  • Average hourly weekday graph: Click “Expand” to add to a larger chart to compare monitoring stations and download graphed data.

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Continually updated from API.

info.name: Data Supplier and processing
info.content: The data is served directly from the Transport NSW API. Data processing for visualisation is managed by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS).

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content: Although every effort has been made to ensure the quality of the data, neither the Institute for Sustainable Futures nor the NSW Roads and Maritime Services can guarantee the accuracy of the data and does not accept responsibility for any consequences arising from its use.

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is a NSW map of average daily traffic volumes at different monitoring stations, recorded in average number of vehicles per day across each reported year. Data displayed is for the primary direction of travel specified (east-west or north-south) and is in annual timesteps from 2015 onwards.

Use the time slider bar at the bottom to explore how traffic volumes and the location of traffic monitoring stations change over time. A number of different display variables can also be selected in the legend panel: road type, all vehicles, heavy vehicles, light vehicles or unclassified vehicles.

In the context of Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning, this is a critical variable that indicates potential demand for charging services, dictated by passing road traffic.

Click on a monitoring station to reveal the following information:

  • Station name
  • Station ID: Code used to identify specific monitoring station
  • LGA; Suburb: Local Government Area and suburb in which the monitoring station is located
  • Road type: Motorway, Arterial road, Sub-Arterial Road, Distributor Road, Primary Road
  • Primary direction captured: Direction of travel presented in the data
  • Vehicle counts:
    • All vehicles: Total number of vehicles of any type
    • Light vehicles: This tends to be passenger vehicles.
    • Heavy vehicles: This tends to be commercial vehicles.
    • Unclassified vehicles: Some stations do not classify vehicles by weight and thus this is generally the same as “All vehicles” for these stations.
  • Daily History: A chart is provided for the daily variations underpinning the average figures. Click “Expand” to add to a larger chart to compare monitoring stations and download graphed data. Select in the legend which directions of travel are graphed (primary direction and/or opposite direction).

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Continually updated from API.

info.name: Data Supplier and processing
info.content: The data is served directly from the Transport NSW API. Data processing for visualisation is managed by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS).

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content: Although every effort has been made to ensure the quality of the data, neither the Institute for Sustainable Futures nor the NSW Roads and Maritime Services can guarantee the accuracy of the data and does not accept responsibility for any consequences arising from its use.

items.name: Community Buildings

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is a filtered subset of the NSW/ACT ‘Places of Interest – All’, including infrastructure (such as utilities, police stations, ambulance stations and hospitals), cultural and leisure sites. It has been filtered to include only the features of potential relevance to Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning. That is, those sites most relevant as attractions that draw customers to an area for leisure activities (such as those which can be undertaken while a vehicle is charging).

NB: Data points are only visible when zoomed in.

The following features are included in the filtered dataset.

info.name: Accuracy
info.content: The dataset maintains a positional relationship to, and alignment with, a range of themes from the NSW FSDF including, transport, Imagery, positioning, water and land cover. It was captured by digitising the best available cadastral mapping at a variety of scales and accuracies, ranging from 1:500 to 1:250 000 according to the National Mapping Council of Australia, Standards of Map Accuracy (1975).

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Dataset on AREMI is updated automatically from the NSW Government spatial services data portal, and is updated by the data supplier as required.

info.name: Data Supplier and Processing
info.content: The data is supplied and hosted by the NSW Government (SS-SDS@customerservice.nsw.gov.au). Data is processed by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS) for display on AREMI.

info.name: Service Description
info.content:
The places of interest layer is served by an ESRI ArcGIS mapserver.

It comprises features whose primary characteristic are of a cultural (man-made) origin, but generally not including transportation related features.

The service is primarily used for planning, developmental activities, navigation and resource monitoring by emergency services, the Defence Forces, environmental resource managers and engineers.

The features in this dataset are captured as part of the NSW Digital Topographic mapping program and can be displayed in their correct relative position with other data themes, eg. Transport.

The service has Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) implemented and is compatible for consumption by common GIS platforms. Available as either cache or non-cache, depending on client use or requirement.

Metadata AS/NZS ISO 19115:
http://www.anzlic.gov.au/resources/anzlic-metadata-profile

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
This is a filtered subset of the NSW/ACT ‘Places of Interest – All’, including infrastructure (such as utilities, police stations, ambulance stations and hospitals), cultural and leisure sites. It has been filtered to include only the features of potential relevance to Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure planning. That is, those sites most relevant as attractions that draw customers to an area for leisure activities (such as those which can be undertaken while a vehicle is charging).

NB: Data points are only visible when zoomed in.

The following features are included in the filtered dataset.

info.name: Accuracy
info.content: The dataset maintains a positional relationship to, and alignment with, a range of themes from the NSW FSDF including, transport, Imagery, positioning, water and land cover. It was captured by digitising the best available cadastral mapping at a variety of scales and accuracies, ranging from 1:500 to 1:250 000 according to the National Mapping Council of Australia, Standards of Map Accuracy (1975).

info.name: Data Updates
info.content: Dataset on AREMI is updated automatically from the NSW Government spatial services data portal, and is updated by the data supplier as required.

info.name: Data Supplier and Processing
info.content: The data is supplied and hosted by the NSW Government (SS-SDS@customerservice.nsw.gov.au). Data is processed by the Institute of Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS) for display on AREMI.

info.name: Service Description
info.content:
The places of interest layer is served by an ESRI ArcGIS mapserver.

It comprises features whose primary characteristic are of a cultural (man-made) origin, but generally not including transportation related features.

The service is primarily used for planning, developmental activities, navigation and resource monitoring by emergency services, the Defence Forces, environmental resource managers and engineers.

The features in this dataset are captured as part of the NSW Digital Topographic mapping program and can be displayed in their correct relative position with other data themes, eg. Transport.

The service has Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) implemented and is compatible for consumption by common GIS platforms. Available as either cache or non-cache, depending on client use or requirement.

Metadata AS/NZS ISO 19115:
http://www.anzlic.gov.au/resources/anzlic-metadata-profile

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
NSW Cadastre web service is a dynamic map of cadastral features extracted from the NSW Digital Cadastral Database (DCDB). It provides access to a state wide integrated database and a component of the foundation spatial datasets within the New South Wales. A ‘cadastre’ is an official register of property showing boundaries. The DCDB contains current land titles only.

The cadastral feature class layers provided through this web service includes:

  • Large Rural Plan Extent
  • Rural Plan Extent
  • Section Extent
  • Plan Extent
  • Lot
  • Plan Extent Labels
  • Section Extent Labels
  • Lot Labels

The available attributes for point queries are:

  • Lot/Section/Plan string
  • CadID

More information can be found here:

http://www.lpi.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/203160/NSW_Cadastre_Web_Service.pdf

items.name: Commonwealth Electoral Divisions (2018) (ABS)
items.description:
The ASGS Commonwealth Electoral Divisions are an ABS approximation of Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) electoral division boundaries. An AEC electoral division boundary is an area legally prescribed for the purpose of returning one member to the House of Representatives, Australia's Federal Lower House of Parliament.

The 2018 Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS) edition of the Commonwealth Electoral Divisions (CED) structure includes updates to the definition of electoral divisions that have occurred prior to 31 July 2018. This updates the 2017 edition of Commonwealth Electoral Divisions released in the [ASGS Volume 3 - Non ABS Structures, July 2017](https://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/by%20Subject/1270.0.55.003~July%202017~Main%20Features~Overview~1). It includes gazetted changes to electoral divisions in Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory.

info.name: Data Description
info.content: The Queensland Imagery (Public) image service displays Landsat 8 imagery over the whole of Queensland, and high resolution imagery, acquired prior to the year 2013, over some areas of the state. The high resolution imagery is that captured under the Spatial Imagery Subscription Plan (SISP) and made available for general use by the Department of Natural Resources and Mines, Queensland. The service uses a map cache currently created for the following scales: 1:2257, 1:4514, 1:9028, 1:18,084, 1:36,112, 1:72,224, 1:144,448, 1:288,895, 1:577,791, 1:1,155,581, 1:2,311,162, 1:4,622,324 and 1:9,244,649. The map service endpoint also displays dynamically to larger scales than those listed. The map cache will be refreshed periodically to show more recent imagery projects as they become available for public use.

info.name: Description
info.content:
‘CSP Indicative firm capacity by thermal storage volume’ is an output of ‘Breaking the Solar Gridlock’ – a research project developed by Institute of Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney (UTS) in collaboration with The Centre for Energy and Environmental Markets, University of New South Wales (UNSW) and The Australian Solar Thermal Energy Association (AUSTELA). Assistance and advice was provided by IT Power. Network partners Ergon Energy in Queensland, Essential Energy and Transgrid in NSW, ElectraNet and SA Power Networks in South Australia, and SP AusNet and Powercor in Victoria, also collaborated on the project and assisted with data provision.



The project was funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), Ergon Energy and AUSTELA. The project’s final report was issued in 2013 and it is available at: [http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf)

The project analyses and maps potentially avoidable network investment and locations where Concentrating Solar Thermal Power (CSP) can address network constraints.

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

This map series shows the “Indicative Firm Capacity” (IFC) of CSP plants with different levels of thermal storage for pick period - summer afternoon and six storage scenarios (0, 1, 3, 5, 10 and 15 hours).

The IFC is essentially an estimate of the probability that CSP with storage would be generating during the key summer and winter peak network constraint periods. To derive the IFC, twenty-one of the highest peak demand events for each state in each of the defined peak time periods during 2009, 2010, and 2011 were selected. info.content:
‘CSP Indicative firm capacity by thermal storage volume’ is an output of ‘Breaking the Solar Gridlock’ – a research project developed by Institute of Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney (UTS) in collaboration with The Centre for Energy and Environmental Markets, University of New South Wales (UNSW) and The Australian Solar Thermal Energy Association (AUSTELA). Assistance and advice was provided by IT Power. Network partners Ergon Energy in Queensland, Essential Energy and Transgrid in NSW, ElectraNet and SA Power Networks in South Australia, and SP AusNet and Powercor in Victoria, also collaborated on the project and assisted with data provision.



The project was funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), Ergon Energy and AUSTELA. The project’s final report was issued in 2013 and it is available at: [http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf)

The project analyses and maps potentially avoidable network investment and locations where Concentrating Solar Thermal Power (CSP) can address network constraints.

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

This map series shows the “Indicative Firm Capacity” (IFC) of CSP plants with different levels of thermal storage for pick period - summer evening and six storage scenarios (0, 1, 3, 5, 10 and 15 hours).

The IFC is essentially an estimate of the probability that CSP with storage would be generating during the key summer and winter peak network constraint periods. To derive the IFC, twenty-one of the highest peak demand events for each state in each of the defined peak time periods during 2009, 2010, and 2011 were selected. It was then modelled whether CSP, with thermal storage configurations varying from 0 to 15 hours, would have been generating during the peak event. An IFC of 0.9 (red areas) indicates that for that peak period, a CSP plant with the number of hours thermal storage selected, would have been generating power during at least 90% of those peak events.

Note that coastal areas have lower values due to the weather systems that generally prevail on the coast. This is also true for tropical northern Queensland, where summers include monsoonal impacts and periods of high rainfall. In winter, Queensland sees higher IFCs because of the absence of monsoonal weather patterns. Also note that IFCs are somewhat higher the further west the plant is located (e.g. northern South Australia).

This modelling shows that IFCs in excess of 80% can be achieved in all seasons and most locations.

[http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-2a-0hr.html](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-2a-0hr.html)

info.content:

Assistance and advice was provided by IT Power. Network partners Ergon Energy in Queensland, Essential Energy and Transgrid in NSW, ElectraNet and SA Power Networks in South Australia, and SP AusNet and Powercor in Victoria, also collaborated on the project and assisted with data provision.



The project was funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), Ergon Energy and AUSTELA. The project’s final report was issued in 2013 and it is available at: [http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf)

The project analyses and maps potentially avoidable network investment and locations where Concentrating Solar Thermal Power (CSP) can address network constraints.

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

This map series shows the “Indicative Firm Capacity” (IFC) of CSP plants with different levels of thermal storage for pick period - winter afternoon and six storage scenarios (0, 1, 3, 5, 10 and 15 hours).

The IFC is essentially an estimate of the probability that CSP with storage would be generating during the key summer and winter peak network constraint periods. To derive the IFC, twenty-one of the highest peak demand events for each state in each of the defined peak time periods during 2009, 2010, and 2011 were selected. It was then modelled whether CSP, with thermal storage configurations varying from 0 to 15 hours, would have been generating during the peak event. An IFC of 0.9 (red areas) indicates that for that peak period, a CSP plant with the number of hours thermal storage selected, would have been generating power during at least 90% of those peak events.

In winter, Queensland sees higher IFCs because of the absence of monsoonal weather patterns. Also note that IFCs are somewhat higher the further west the plant is located (e.g. northern South Australia).

This modelling shows that IFCs in excess of 80% can be achieved in all seasons and most locations.

This modelling shows that IFCs in excess of 80% can be achieved in all seasons and most locations.

info.name: Description
info.content:
‘CSP Indicative firm capacity by thermal storage volume’ is an output of ‘Breaking the Solar Gridlock’ – a research project developed by Institute of Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney (UTS) in collaboration with The Centre for Energy and Environmental Markets, University of New South Wales (UNSW) and The Australian Solar Thermal Energy Association (AUSTELA). Assistance and advice was provided by IT Power. Network partners Ergon Energy in Queensland, Essential Energy and Transgrid in NSW, ElectraNet and SA Power Networks in South Australia, and SP AusNet and Powercor in Victoria, also collaborated on the project and assisted with data provision.



The project was funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), Ergon Energy and AUSTELA. The project’s final report was issued in 2013 and it is available at: [http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf)

The project analyses and maps potentially avoidable network investment and locations where Concentrating Solar Thermal Power (CSP) can address network constraints.

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

This map series shows the “Indicative Firm Capacity” (IFC) of CSP plants with different levels of thermal storage for pick period - winter evening and six storage scenarios (0, 1, 3, 5, 10 and 15 hours).

The IFC is essentially an estimate of the probability that CSP with storage would be generating during the key summer and winter peak network constraint periods. To derive the IFC, twenty-one of the highest peak demand events for each state in each of the defined peak time periods during 2009, 2010, and 2011 were selected. It was then modelled whether CSP, with thermal storage configurations varying from 0 to 15 hours, would have been generating during the peak event. An IFC of 0.9 (red areas) indicates that for that peak period, a CSP plant with the number of hours thermal storage selected, would have been generating power during at least 90% of those peak events.

Note that coastal areas have lower values due to the weather systems that generally prevail on the coast. This is also true for tropical northern Queensland, where summers include monsoonal impacts and periods of high rainfall. In winter, Queensland sees higher IFCs because of the absence of monsoonal weather patterns. Also note that IFCs are somewhat higher the further west the plant is located (e.g. northern South Australia).

This modelling shows that IFCs in excess of 80% can be achieved in all seasons and most locations.

For more information about the project and data used for generating the maps:

[http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-2a-0hr.html](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-2a-0hr.html)

info.name: Description
info.content:
‘CSP as an alternative to network augmentation – Cost Benefit’ is an output of ‘Breaking the Solar Gridlock’ – a research project developed by Institute of Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney (UTS) in collaboration with The Centre for Energy and Environmental Markets, University of New South Wales (UNSW) and The Australian Solar Thermal Energy Association (AUSTELA). Assistance and advice was provided by IT Power. Network partners Ergon Energy in Queensland, Essential Energy and Transgrid in NSW, ElectraNet and SA Power Networks in South Australia, and SP AusNet and Powercor in Victoria, also collaborated on the project and assisted with data provision.

The project was funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), Ergon Energy and AUSTELA. The project’s final report was issued in 2013 and it is available at:

[http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/documents/Breakingthesolargridlock_finalv2.pdf)

The project analyses and maps potentially avoidable network investment and locations where Concentrating Solar Thermal Power (CSP) can address network constraints.

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

These maps indicate that CSP could avoid the need for network augmentation in 48 locations, or 72% of the constrained locations examined. If only locations with solar resources better than 21 MJ/m2/day DNI are included, CSP could avoid the need for augmentation at 94% of locations.
  • The coloured shapes mark the grid constraints in areas where the solar resource is sufficiently high to warrant the investigation of CSP. A circle shows that CSP is able to meet the network constraint; a square that CSP cannot meet the constraint; and a triangle is where there is insufficient information to reach a conclusion.
  • The colour of the shape indicates the CSP cost-gap after taking into account a network support payment. Green areas are where the modelling indicates a positive CSP business case, while red indicates a substantial cost-gap.
  • The size of the circle is proportional to the most cost effective plant capital cost
  • Clicking on a shape gives detailed information.


Altogether, installation of 533MW of CSP at grid constrained locations was found to be cost effective during the next 10 years, and an additional 125MW had a cost benefit greater than -$20/MWh. Installation of this CSP would save approximately 1.9 MT of greenhouse gases per year.

For more information about the project and data used for generating the maps:

[http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-3a.html](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-3a.html)

This project investigated whether network support payments for installing CSP at grid constrained locations in the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM) could bridge the cost gap for CSP, while achieving societal savings in the costs of addressing network constraints. The project quantifies the potential economic benefits from installing CSP at grid constrained locations, and maps where CSP could provide cost-effective network support services.

The project found that CSP can offer a commercially viable alternative to traditional network augmentation solutions in addressing electricity grid constraints. The study identified $0.8 billion of potentially avoidable network investment, and 533 MW of cost effective CSP which could be installed at grid constrained locations in the next 10 years. This would reduce greenhouse emissions by 1.9 million tonnes per year.

These maps indicate that CSP could avoid the need for network augmentation in 48 locations, or 72% of the constrained locations examined. If only locations with solar resources better than 21 MJ/m2/day DNI are included, CSP could avoid the need for augmentation at 94% of locations.
  • The coloured shapes mark the grid constraints in areas where the solar resource is sufficiently high to warrant the investigation of CSP. A circle shows that CSP is able to meet the network constraint; a square that CSP cannot meet the constraint; and a triangle is where there is insufficient information to reach a conclusion.
  • The colour of the shape indicates the CSP cost-gap after taking into account a network support payment. Green areas are where the modelling indicates a positive CSP business case, while red indicates a substantial cost-gap.
  • The size of the circle is proportional to the most cost effective plant capital cost
  • Clicking on a shape gives detailed information.


Altogether, installation of 533MW of CSP at grid constrained locations was found to be cost effective during the next 10 years, and an additional 125MW had a cost benefit greater than -$20/MWh. Installation of this CSP would save approximately 1.9 MT of greenhouse gases per year.

For more information about the project and data used for generating the maps:

[http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-3a.html](http://breakingthesolargridlock.net/maps/map-3a.html)

info.name: Description

info.name: NEAR Program Overview
info.content:
The NEAR Program is focussed on bringing together energy datasets from across the Australian energy sector and delivering a comprehensive research program focussed on what drives and shapes Australian energy consumption behaviour, from individual households and businesses to our national energy use trends. The team behind NEAR curates public data assets, works with data holders to release previously private data, deploys cutting-edge data science techniques to expand the value of existing data, and leads brand new data collection and research efforts to fill critical gaps for the energy sector. We collaborate with industry, science and government organisations, and engage with the Australian people to deliver a diverse collection of assets that will inform future Australian decision making across the sector.

NEAR is funded by the Commonwealth Department of the Environment and Energy (DEE) and delivered by Australia’s national science agency, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).
