info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
A number of CSIRO Energise surveys have included demographics questions, such as household composition and income. Here we present some key items.

Household Size

Including yourself, how many people usually live in your household?

Contextual help: In some households, the number of occupants can vary from time to time. Please answer this question in terms of the number of people who live in your home at least half of the time.

  • Size - 1: 1 person
  • Size - 2: 2 persons
  • Size - 3: 3 persons
  • Size - 4: 4 persons
  • Size - 5 or more: 5 or more persons

Household Type

Which of the following best describes your household?

  • Type - Lone Person: Lone person household - single person living alone
  • Type - Family with Children: One family household - couple with children (including adult children)
  • Type - Family no Children: One family household - couple with no children
  • Type - Single Parent: One family household - one parent family with children (including adult children)
  • Type - Other: Includes multiple family households and share houses

Tenure

In terms of home ownership, is your dwelling:

  • Tenure - Owned: Owned or partly owned by someone in your household
  • Tenure - Rental Property: Being rented by your household
  • Tenure - Other: Other (e.g. occupied rent-free)

Household Income

What is your total household income per year, before tax?

Contextual help: That is, the total of all wages/salaries, government benefits, pensions, allowances and other income (e.g. dividends, interest) your household usually receives. Do not deduct tax.

  • Income - Less than $33,800: Total household income less than $33,800 per year
  • Income - $33,800-$78,000: Total household income between $33,800 and $78,000 per year
  • Income - Greater than $78,000: Total household income over $78,000 per year
  • Income - Prefer not to say: No response offered

info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
A number of CSIRO Energise surveys have included questions about building characteristics, such as dwelling age and the number of bedrooms, and the use of gas and solar generation. Here we present some key items.

Dwelling Type

What type of dwelling do you live in?

  • Dwelling - House: Separate House
  • Dwelling - Semi-detached: Semi-detached, row or terrace house or townhouse (e.g. duplex or villa)
  • Dwelling - Multi-dwelling building: Flat, unit or apartment
  • Dwelling - Other: Other type of dwelling

Bedrooms

How many bedrooms does your home have?

Contextual help: If you live in a studio apartment or another type of dwelling without any separate bedrooms, please answer '0' (numerical range limit: 0 to 20).

  • Bedrooms - 0-1: 0 or 1 bedroom
  • Bedrooms - 2: 2 bedrooms
  • Bedrooms - 3: 3 bedrooms
  • Bedrooms - 4: 4 bedrooms
  • Bedrooms - 5 or more: 5 or more bedrooms, numerical limit 20

Dwelling Age

Approximately, in what year was your home constructed?

  • Age - Pre-1970:
  • Age - 1970-1989:
  • Age - 1990-2009:
  • Age - 2010-2015:
  • Age - 2016+:
  • Age - Unknown: Don't know

Homes with Gas

Does your household use mains gas or bottled gas/LPG as an energy source?

Contextual help: LPG stands for Liquefied Petroleum Gas, but it may be referred to as propane or butane. It is sometimes used as fuel for heating, hot water, cooking and for other appliances. Respondents could choose both mains and bottled gas, hence a total greater than 100% is possible.

  • Gas - Percentage: Percentage of homes with gas, including mains or bottled gas

Homes with Solar

Does your household have solar panels to generate electricity?

  • Solar - Percentage: Percentage of homes with solar - count of 'yes' / total respondents.

info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
CSIRO Energise survey participants were asked a number of questions about the type and usage of heating appliances, and their level of comfort with and without heating.

Type of Heating Appliance

What type(s) of heating does your household have? (select all that apply)

  • Type - Wood/Coal: Wood or coal fire
  • Type - Ducted: Gas or electric central heating
  • Type - Under Floor: Gas or electric under floor heating
  • Type - Air Conditioner: Air conditioning unit(s) that are used as heater(s)
  • Type - Other: Other type(s) of heating
  • Type - None: N/A – do not have any heating

Heating in the past week

Thinking about the past seven days, how many days did your household use at least one heater or heating system?

Contextual help: If your household did not use any heating in the past seven days, please answer ‘0’.

  • Usage - 0 Days: Not used
  • Usage - 1-2 Days: 1-2 Days
  • Usage - 3-4 Days: 3-4 Days
  • Usage - 5-6 Days: 4-5 Days
  • Usage - 7 Days: Every day

Comfort with Heating

Thinking about the past seven days, how did you feel at home when the heating was on?

  • Comfort with Heating - Much Colder: A lot colder than I would have liked
  • Comfort with Heating - Slightly Colder: A little colder than I would have liked
  • Comfort with Heating - Comfortable: Comfortable
  • Comfort with Heating - Slightly Hotter: A little hotter than I would have liked
  • Comfort with Heating - Much Hotter: A lot hotter than I would have liked
  • Comfort with Heating - N/A: Not at home, not in the room(s) being heated, or heating was always off

Comfort without Heating

Thinking about the past seven days, how did you feel at home when the heating was off?

  • Comfort without Heating - Much Colder: A lot colder than I would have liked
  • Comfort without Heating - Slightly Colder: A little colder than I would have liked
  • Comfort without Heating - Comfortable: Comfortable
  • Comfort without Heating - Slightly Hotter: A little hotter than I would have liked
  • Comfort without Heating - Much Hotter: A lot hotter than I would have liked
  • Comfort without Heating - N/A: Not at home, or heating was always on

info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
CSIRO Energise participants were surveyed on their household bills, such as electricity tariffs, rebates, monthly cost and daily usage. Here we present a summary of their responses.

Electricity Tariff

What type of electricity tariff are you on? (select all that apply).

This should appear on your bill where the electricity charges are listed.

  • Tariff - Flat Rate: Single or flat rate tariff – electricity price is fixed, so you pay the same rate whatever time of day you use electricity
  • Tariff - Flexible Pricing: Time of use or flexible pricing tariff – electricity price varies depending on the time of day, so you pay different rates for peak and off-peak times
  • Tariff - Demand: Bill includes a daily ‘demand’ or ‘capacity’ charge, based on your maximum electricity use (i.e. your highest power demand) at a point in time, typically during peak periods
  • Tariff - Controlled Load: One or more appliances (e.g. hot water system, underfloor heating, pool pump) have separate meters, and you usually pay a lower rate for the electricity used by such appliances.
  • Tariff - Other: Other tariff
  • Tariff - Unknown: Don't know

Rebates and Discounts

What type of discount, rebate or concession do you receive? (select all that apply)

  • Rebate - On-Time Payment: Pay on time discount – when you pay your bill by the due date
  • Rebate - Paperless Billing: Paperless billing discount – when you receive your bill electronically (e.g. email) rather than by post
  • Rebate - Direct Debit Discount: PDirect debit discount – when money is automatically deducted from your bank account or credit card to pay your bill
  • Rebate - Bundled: Bundled discount – when you buy both electricity and gas from the same retailer
  • Rebate - Government Concession: Government energy concession – available to pensioners, low income earners, customers with certain medical conditions, and other eligible concession card holders
  • Rebate - Other: Other rebate, discount and/or concession
  • Rebate - Unknown: Don't know
  • Rebate - None: Don't receive any rebate or discount

Monthly Energy Cost

Bill: In dollars, how much is your household’s most recent electricity bill? Please give the total amount payable.

Contextual help: Please give the total amount payable. This should be listed as the ‘amount due’ on your bill. If you don’t know the answer, please leave the question blank.

Period: Looking at your household’s most recent electricity bill, over what period of time does this bill cover?

Monthly energy cost has been calculated as Bill / Period

  • Cost - less than $100:
  • Cost - $100-200:
  • Cost - $200-300:
  • Cost - over $300:

Average Daily Usage (kWh)

According to your most recent bill, what is your household’s average daily electricity usage (in kWh)?

Contextual help: The average daily usage should be displayed in a chart or table on your bill. kWh stands for kilowatt hour. It is the unit of measurement for your electricity usage.

  • Usage - 0-10 kWh:
  • Usage - 10-20 kWh:
  • Usage - 20-30 kWh:
  • Usage - 30+ kWh:

info.name: CSIRO Energise Overview
info.content:
Here we present an ongoing series of result snapshots from surveys delivered through the CSIRO Energise mobile app.

The CSIRO Energise app enables on-demand, near-real-time delivery and capture of surveys through a user-friendly interface, and has been specifically developed to allow Australian households to contribute to national energy research through responses to micro-surveys on topics related to household energy behaviour and sentiment.

For further information on CSIRO Energise, visit CSIRO Energise or download it from your favourite app store today.

info.name: Distribution Network Service Provider (DNSP) Zone Substation Data Overview
info.content:
The National Energy Analytics Research (NEAR) Program has brought together up to a decade of half-hourly electricity consumption data for more than one thousand zone substations across Australia’s electricity distribution systems. Including data that has never before been publicly released, the zone substation dataset is a rich view into the longitudinal load consumption behaviour of Australian electricity users. The data is presented in a consistent format across distribution businesses and available for free on the NEAR platform.

Note that Distribution Network Service Providers (DNSPs) have not analysed, assessed or validated the quality or accuracy of the original, cleaned, modified or geospatially visualised datasets. Distribution Network Service Providers make no warranty or guarantee as to the quality, accuracy or suitability for any particular purpose of the zone substation information.

DNSPs represented:

  • ActewAGL: ACT, now Evoenergy
  • Ausgrid: New South Wales
  • AusNet Services: Victoria
  • CitiPower: Victoria
  • Endeavour Energy: New South Wales
  • Energex: Queensland
  • Ergon Energy: Queensland
  • Essential Energy: New South Wales
  • Powercor: Victoria
  • SA Power Networks: South Australia
  • TasNetworks: Tasmania
  • United Energy: Victoria
  • Western Power: Western Australia

DNSPs not represented:

  • Horizon Power: Western Australia, no region mapping data available at this time.
  • Power and Water Corporation: Northern Territory, no load or region mapping data available at this time.

info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
Here we present yearly summaries of Zone Substation Load Data, including estimated total active energy, maximum and minimum supply, and standard deviation of interval measurements.

The dataset spans the year range 2003 to 2018. An individual DNSP or zone substation may not have data available for every year in this range. This is indicated by a grey colouring on the map. A zone substation may not have data for a complete year. This can be determined by the Start and End Delivery Time. The summary statistics are calculated between between Start and End Delivery Time for the specified calendar year. Where data was provided in apparent power units, a simple conversion to real power units was applied, assuming a constant power factor of 0.9.

  • Utility Name: DNSP name
  • Supply Region Name: Zone Substation name
  • Supply Region ID: DNSP's identifier for the Zone Substation
  • Year: Calendar year
  • Start Delivery Time: Timestamp of first supply recorded for the year.
  • End Delivery Time: Timestamp of last supply recorded for the year. 'year+1'-01-01 00:00:00 indicates the end of the calendar year.
  • Total Active Energy (MWh): Total energy supplied by the Zone Substation
  • Minimum Power (MW): Minimum power supplied by the Zone Substation
  • Maximum Power (MW): Maximum power supplied by the Zone Substation
  • Mean Power (MW): Mean of interval measurements
  • Median Power (MW): Median of interval measurements
  • Standard Deviation (MW): Standard Deviation of interval measurements
  • Coefficient of Variation: Standard Deviation / Mean Power

info.content: National Energy Analytics Research Program (NEAR), from data provided by Australian distribution network businesses.

info.content: Spatial data as at 2016; electrical load data as specified.

info.content: The original zone substation information was provided to CSIRO as raw data. CSIRO has cleaned and translated the raw data, but the Distribution Network Service Provider has not analysed, assessed or validated the quality or accuracy of the original, cleaned, modified or geospatially visualised datasets. The Distribution Network Service Provider makes no warranty or guarantee as to the quality, accuracy or suitability for any particular purpose of the zone substation information.      For full terms and conditions, please see: https://near.csiro.au/termsOfUse

info.name: Dataset Description
info.content:
Here we present a characterisation of Zone Substations in terms of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Mesh Block (MB) land use categories, dwellings and persons. Areal interpolation has been used to reaggregate data from the ABS Mesh Block geometry to the Zone Substation geometry, using the intersection of polygons. This method has a number of limitations:

  • Assumption of distribution: MBs areas are small, but there may be instances where a MB intersects with multiple Zone Substations. Statistics have been calculated using the proportionality of the area of intersection. This may not reflect the physical distribution, such as the location of dwellings and persons.
  • Accuracy of spatial data: The ABS geometry is generally accurate than the DNSP geometry.

Mesh Block Categories are expressed as percentages - Area given to Category / Zone Substation area.

Estimation of Persons and Dwellings according to ABS 2016 Mesh Block Counts. Display variables:

  • DNSP: Name of the Distribution Network Service Provider
  • State/Territory: State or Territory of the Distribution Network Service Provider
  • Zone Substation Name: Name of the Zone Substation
  • Zone Substation ID: DNSP's identifier for the Zone Substation
  • Zone Substation Area (km2): Zone Substation area in square kilometres
  • Dwellings: Approximate number of dwellings in the Zone Substation area
  • Persons: Approximate population of the Zone Substation area
  • Residential: Houses, apartments, duplexes, etc
  • Commercial: Businesses, shops, etc, generally zero population count
  • Industrial: Businesses, generally zero population count
  • Primary Production: > 50% primary production, formerly known as Agricultural
  • Education: Schools, universities, etc
  • Hospital/Medical: Hospital or medical facilities, aged care
  • Transport: Road and rail features
  • Parkland: Parkland, nature reserves, public open space, etc
  • Water: Water bodies, lakes, etc
  • Other: Not easily categorised, high mixed use

info.name: Disclaimer
info.content:
The Australian Renewable Energy Mapping Infrastructure (AREMI) website implements a geospatial map viewer which is intended for viewing over the internet. The AREMI website is being developed by National ICT Australia Limited (NICTA) in collaboration with Geoscience Australia (GA) and with funding support from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA). ARENA invests in renewable energy projects, supports research and development activities, boosts job creation and industry development, and increases knowledge about renewable energy. The AREMI website is an information service that is intended to be accessible to all interested external parties. The AREMI website provides access to renewable energy and general information which has been provided by various third party data custodians. As a condition of using this website, users should understand and must accept, that the information and data provided on the AREMI website:
  • is entirely dependant on the accuracy of the information and data which has been provided by the third party data custodians;
  • is not necessarily complete;
  • sometimes is general in nature; and
  • should not be relied on in place of independent research and professional advice, including in later stages of investment and planning processes.

ARENA, NICTA and GA, do not warrant, and are not liable for the accuracy of the information and data on the AREMI website.

info.name: Description of Data
info.content:
The Solar Station Historical Observation (SSHO) data layer is a derivative created by AREMI and based on the Bureau of Meteorology One Minute Solar data (described in detail under Source Data below). The One Minute Solar data was processed using the aremi-tmy tool, due to be Open Sourced soon at the following URL:

https://github.com/NICTA/aremi-tmy/

The aremi-tmy tool will be used to generate Typical Meteorological Year (TMY) data. As part of the processing an intermediate output is the SSHO data. The SSHO was generated by placing the Bureau One Minute Solar data values into hourly buckets, and calculating the arithmetic mean per hour. Any data gaps of less than 5 hours were linearly interpolated (by individual field, e.g. missing temperature data is treated independently from other fields which may or may not also be missing). Following the 5 hour interpolation, gaps of 24 hours or less are filled by using data from the same time in the previous or next day. Gaps larger than this were ignored and are therefore still present in the SSHO. As a result of this processing, this is a more complete dataset compared to the One Minute Solar data, but with less resolution.

The SSHO data available here was processed using the aremi-tmy version 0.1.1.0 tool from the source Bureau One Minute Solar data. Start dates for the Bureau's One Minute Solar data and the period over which stations have made solar observations vary significantly. The first sites began recording solar data in 1993, while the most recently opened sites commenced in 2012. Some stations are now closed. The number of years of data recorded can be accessed by clicking on the station to display the site data.

info.name: Source Data
info.content:
The Bureau One Minute Solar data includes a range of solar statistics, including global, diffuse, direct and terrestrial irradiance and sunshine-seconds.

One Minute Solar data is not based on a real-time product. Data is processed by the Bureau of Meteorology nominally at one to two monthly intervals.

The Bureau of Meteorology has been measuring a range of solar parameters for several decades. The development of a new high quality observation system, which first became operational in 1993, has facilitated the measurement of one minute solar statistics. Data have been recorded at 29 locations, however not all stations have this data visualisation, nor data for the entire period since 1993.

The Bureau of Meteorology does not endorse the derivative data or visualisations available on the AREMI website.

Detailed information about the One Minute Solar data, including a list of the observation stations, is available here:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data/oneminsolar/about-IDCJAC0022.shtml

Should AREMI users want to source the raw One Minute Solar data with the latest updates, they should contact the Bureau of Meteorology – Climate Information Services:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data-services/

A list of charges is available here:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data-services/charges.shtml

info.name: Updates
info.content:
No updates to the SSHO data to incorporate more recent One Minute Solar source data are currently planned.

As the aremi-tmy tool develops, the source data may be re-processed using newer versions. The current data available on AREMI was processed using aremi-tmy version 0.1.1.0.

Should AREMI users want to source the raw data with the latest updates, they should contact the Bureau of Meteorology – Climate Information Services:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data-services/

A list of charges is available here:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data-services/charges.shtml

Alternatively, data can be freely downloaded per month, per station, by registering here:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data/oneminsolar/solar_user_reg.shtml

The Bureau of Meteorology offers users the option to subscribe to an RSS feed for notifications on the One Minute Solar data updates.

info.name: Data Custodian
info.content:
The Bureau of Meteorology is the data custodian of the source One Minute Solar Observations data.

The Bureau of Meteorology provides Australians with environmental intelligence for safety, sustainability, well-being and prosperity. It aims to promote informed safety, security and economic decisions by governments, industry, and the community through the provision of information, forecasts, services and research relating to weather, climate and water.

info.name: Licensing, Terms & Conditions
info.content:
The visualisation of One Minute Solar Observations data on the AREMI platform is attributed to the Commonwealth of Australia acting through the Bureau of Meteorology.

The Bureau of Meteorology grants NICTA a non-transferable, non-exclusive licence to make the SSHO data (derived from the Bureau of meteorology One minute solar observation data) available on the AREMI platform.

If visitors of the AREMI website are interested in sourcing the one minute solar observation source data from which the SSHO data is derived, they should contact the Bureau of Meteorology directly via:

http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/data-services/data-requests.shtml

Below is an extract from ‘Bureau Access Agreement Covering External Party Usage of Bureau Information’ – Access Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia acting through the Bureau of Meteorology (the “Bureau”) and the User (NICTA).

1.1 The Bureau grants NICTA, in respect of the data and information made available by the Bureau to NICTA for AREMI project, a non-transferable, non-exclusive licence to:

(b) supply the Information to third parties where it is incorporated as part of a User product on the terms and conditions set out in this Agreement.

1.2 The User (i.e. NICTA) must not supply the Information to third parties as is, except as part of a User product (i.e. in this case, AREMI visualisation platform). Where a third party (i.e. AREMI user) requests access to the Information itself, the User must advise the third party to contact the Bureau for the purpose of obtaining the Information directly from the Bureau.

info.name: Description of Data
info.content:
The Typical Meteorological Year (TMY) data is a derivative created by AREMI and based on the Bureau of Meteorology One Minute Solar data. The One Minute Solar data was processed using the aremi-tmy tool, due to be Open Sourced soon at the following URL:

https://github.com/NICTA/aremi-tmy/

As part of the processing an intermediate more complete timeseries output is created, referred to as the Solar Station Historical Observation (SSHO) data, which is also available on AREMI. The SSHO was generated by placing the Bureau One Minute Solar data values into hourly buckets, and calculating the arithmetic mean per hour. Any data gaps of less than 5 hours were linearly interpolated (by individual field, e.g. missing temperature data is treated independently from other fields which may or may not also be missing). Following the 5 hour interpolation, gaps of 24 hours or less are filled by using data from the same time in the previous or next day. Gaps larger than this were ignored and are therefore still present in the SSHO. As a result of this processing, this is a more complete dataset compared to the One Minute Solar data, but with less resolution.

After the One Minute Solar data has been processed into the SSHO timeseries, further processing takes place to analyse the separate months of timeseries data to determine the "most typical" months. This analysis is based on the Sandia Method as detailed by S. Wilcox and W. Marion in 'Users Manual for TMY3 Data Sets', NREL.

In order to generate a TMY for a station it is a requirement that at least one of the calendar months has data from at least 9 different years.

The TMY data available here was processed using the aremi-tmy version 0.1.1.0 tool from the source Bureau One Minute Solar data. Start dates for the Bureau's One Minute Solar data and the period over which stations have made solar observations vary significantly. The first sites began recording solar data in 1993, while the most recently opened sites commenced in 2012. Some stations are now closed. The number of years of data recorded can be accessed by clicking on the station to display the site data.
